bestBHT.bht: Jesus began his discourse, declaring the fulfillment of the Messianic prophecy of Isaiah. By his preaching, he emphasized that the prophecy was heard, not seen, and that doctrine held great importance. Jesus proclaimed himself as the fulfillment of the Scripture, preaching glad tidings. As the sent Messiah, he brought about the restoration of God's church, fulfilling the prophecy.

Henry Alford: he began to say,—implying that the following words are merely the substance of a more expanded discourse"
see another occasion in Matt. xi. 4, 5, where the same truth was declared by a series of gracious acts of mercy."
fulfilled in your ears, viz. by My proclaiming it, and My course of ministry.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: whole address was just a detailed application to Himself of this and
Albert Barnes: This scripture - This writing, or this part of the Scriptures.
Fulfilled - It is coming to pass; the thing originally intended by it is about to be accomplished.
In your ears - In your 'hearing;' or you hear, in my preaching, the fulfillment of this prophecy.
Marvin Vincent: He began. Not necessarily denoting his first words, but indicating a solemn and weighty opening.
John Calvin: Today is fulfilled... the time was now come, when it was the will of God to restore his ruined church.
The object of his discourse was, to expound the prediction clearly to his hearers.
He says that it was fulfilled in their ears, rather than in their eyes, because the bare sight of the fact was of little value if doctrine had not held the chief place.
Philip Schaff: And he began to say. This was both the actual beginning of His discourse, and its theme and substance."
That He explained the passage at some length seems probable from the next verse.
Today hath this Scripture been fulfilled in your ears. By the presence of Jesus the Messiah speaking to them. Equally apt as an opening sentence, and as the sum of His discourse.
Archibald T. Robertson: Today this scripture ... stands fulfilled in your ears.
Jesus could only mean that ... the Messianic prophecy of Isaiah had come true today.
And it is no apocalyptic eschatological Messiah whom Jesus here sets forth.
John Gill: I am the person here spoken of; and at this present time the Spirit of God is upon me; I am anointed with the Holy Ghost, and now preach glad tidings to you."
This Scripture has its full accomplishment which has been read unto you, and you have heard this day."
The holy, blessed God, will send his Messiah to us, and he shall be worthy of this, as it is said, 'he hath sent me to preach glad tidings to the meek.'
John Wesley: To-day is this scripture fulfilled in your ears — By what you hear me speak.

bhtAttempts.bht: He began his discourse with a solemn and weighty opening, declaring that the Messianic prophecy of Isaiah had come true that day. Jesus emphasized that the fulfillment of the prophecy was heard in his preaching, rather than seen, as doctrine held the chief place. His words were not merely the substance of an expanded discourse, but the actual beginning and theme of his message. By his presence and anointing of the Holy Spirit, Jesus proclaimed himself as the fulfillment of the Scripture, preaching glad tidings to his hearers. The time had come for God to restore his ruined church, and Jesus, as the anointed Messiah, was the one whom God had sent to fulfill the prophecy.

Jesus began his discourse with a solemn opening, declaring the fulfillment of the Messianic prophecy of Isaiah, emphasizing that it was heard in his preaching, rather than seen. His words were not only the substance of an expanded discourse, but the actual theme of his message. By his presence and anointing of the Holy Spirit, Jesus proclaimed himself as the fulfillment of the Scripture, preaching glad tidings to his hearers. The time had come for God to restore his church, and Jesus was the anointed Messiah sent by God to fulfill the prophecy.

Jesus began his discourse with a solemn opening, declaring the fulfillment of the Messianic prophecy of Isaiah. By his preaching, Jesus emphasized that the prophecy was heard, not seen, as doctrine held great importance. His words were not just a mere expansion, but the actual theme of his message. Through his presence and anointing, Jesus proclaimed himself as the fulfillment of the Scripture, preaching glad tidings. As the sent Messiah, Jesus brought about the restoration of God's church, bringing the prophecy to its full accomplishment.

Jesus began his discourse, declaring the fulfillment of the Messianic prophecy of Isaiah. By his preaching, he emphasized that the prophecy was heard, not seen, and that doctrine held great importance. Jesus proclaimed himself as the fulfillment of the Scripture, preaching glad tidings. As the sent Messiah, he brought about the restoration of God's church, fulfilling the prophecy.

By his preaching, he emphasized that the prophecy was heard, not seen, and that doctrine held great importance. Jesus proclaimed himself as the fulfillment of the Scripture, preaching glad tidings. As the sent Messiah, he brought about the restoration of God's church, fulfilling the prophecy.
